entry.title: 单元测试的实践
entry.summary: 概述
entry.content:
概述​

之前 和 之前 对几个测试框架做过一些浅尝则止的练习，但是对于测试目的，测试方式不甚理解。最近读了一篇文章感觉颇有启发，结合一下其他学习资料，在此拾人牙慧。

软件工程中的测试，整体目标是为了保证项目代码的可用性，稳定性，功能符合预期。主要是通过自动化的手段，对代码、组件、应用进行测试，以确保代码的可用性与稳定性。

本文主要讲的是单元测试的实践。

测试思路​

从测试目的出发，反推测试过程，有利于测试用例的编写。

单元测试的测试对象通常是对项目代码中粒度较小的内容，常见的如函数，组件。

测试目的当然是该单元的运行与预期相符。

比方说：

  • 对于纯函数，给定输入，函数的运行结果应当和预期输出一致。

  • 对于组件，给定属性 props ，组件渲染结果中应当包含预期的元素。

事实上的某些待测试的函数会有副作用 side-effect，组件也会依赖其他组件，此时为这个单元进行测试的时候，就需要对它的依赖进行模拟，俗称打桩 stub (mock)。

对于不同形式的副作用，打桩形式也不一样。

副作用形式打桩思路
依赖并修改外部状态模拟状态，确保其在运行前后的变更符合预期。
依赖外部函数，但不依赖返回结果模拟函数，确保其调用参数、调用次数符合预期。
依赖外部函数，同时依赖对应返回结果模拟函数，并且以入参正确的模拟不同输出。确保待测函数按照返回结果的运行符合预期。
依赖子组件，仅渲染无交互shallow render，确保子组件存在即可。参考 enzyme shallow ， vitest stub and shallow
依赖子组件，依赖交互full render，子组件跟普通子元素地位相当。模拟触发事件功能，预期回调正确执行。参考 enzyme mount ， vitest component
依赖定时器 timer各个测试库均会提供 fakeTimer 。预期随着时间的变化，函数调用、状态变更应当符合预期。

测试实践​

纯函数​

纯函数的测试比较简单，不过编写测试用例时，需要把所有分支覆盖。

export function calculate(
  operand1: number,
  operand2: number,
  operator: '+' | '-'
): number {
  switch (operator) {
    case '+':
      return operand1 + operand2;
    case '-':
      return operand1 - operand2;
    default:
      throw new Error('Unknown operator');
  }
}

test('calculate', () => {
  expect(calculate(2, 3, '+')).toBe(5);
  expect(calculate(3, 2, '-')).toBe(1);
  // @ts-expect-error
  expect(() => calculate(2, 2, '*')).toThrow(/Unknown operator/);
});

外部状态​

为了便于测试函数运行时修改外部状态的情形，需要将状态导出，或至少提供一种方式能够读取状态。如果是其他全局状态同理。

// directly export
export const store = {
  count: 1,
};

// export an API for accessing
export const getCount = () => store.count;

export const increment = (value = 1) => {
  store.count += value;
};

// reset the store
beforeEach(() => {
  store.count = 10;
});

test('store', () => {
  expect(store.count).toBe(10);
  increment(20);
  expect(getCount()).toBe(30);
});

函数依赖​

对于依赖函数的场景可以有两种实践方式。方式一，观察。注意要将目标导出，并且在对象中观察。

export const howOld = (name: string, age: number) => {
  console.log(`${name} is ${age} years old`);
};

export const report = () => {
  howOld('Bob', 12);
};

// group as object so that jest can spyOn
import * as functions from './functions';
test('function', () => {
  const spy = jest.spyOn(functions, 'howOld');
  expect(spy).toHaveBeenCalledTimes(0);
  functions.report();
  expect(spy).toHaveBeenCalledTimes(1);
  expect(spy).toHaveBeenCalledWith('Bob', 12);
});

方式二，mock 函数。校验思路与前者一直。mock 函数时，也需要实现对应的返回结果，以达到测试目的。

export const report = (fn: (name: string, age: number) => string): string => {
  return fn('Alice', 12);
};

test('function', () => {
  const spy = jest.fn().mockReturnValue('default');
  expect(spy).toHaveBeenCalledTimes(0);
  expect(report(spy)).toBe('default');
  expect(spy).toHaveBeenCalledTimes(1);
  expect(spy).toHaveBeenCalledWith('Alice', 12);
});

子组件依赖​

子组件的依赖可以直接读文档 enzyme shallow 、 vitest stub and shallow 、 enzyme mount 、 vitest component 的例子，此处不再冗余。

测试核心目标主要包括：

  • 确保组件正确渲染；

  • 确保组件交互事件触发时，回调正确执行或状态变更符合预期；

  • 确保组件渲染时 hooks 等副作用正确执行。

entry.title: 设计一个 CLI 工具
entry.summary: 自从接手编辑器的 CLI 工具以来，我对原始的代码设计深恶痛绝。只是无奈重构、升级等迟迟无法提上日程，所以只能在这里做大梦。
entry.content:
自从接手编辑器的 CLI 工具以来，我对原始的代码设计深恶痛绝。只是无奈重构、升级等迟迟无法提上日程，所以只能在这里做大梦。

常见工具​

在 Node 中，我接触过的 CLI 开发工具有

  • common-bin
  • commander
  • oclif

相比较而言，前两个 common-bin 和 commander 只能算是 CLI 的开发工具套件 (library) ，而 oclif 可以称得上 CLI 开发框架。

用 Web 生态去类比，前两者好比就是 React 和 Vue ，属于 Web UI library 。作为核心库，它们只提供了 MVVM 的功能，诸如 router 、store 、http 等都需要同生态下的其他 library 支持。

而 oclif 更接近 Angular 这种结结实实的 Web 框架。除了有开箱即用，省去绝大部分的工具类选型烦恼的优点，还有 schematics 这种好东西帮助开发提效。我这里有个 示例项目 可以带你入门 Angular 的 schematics。

设计 CLI​

抛开基础工具的选型，一款理想的 CLI 工具使用方式设计为

# 命令       全局选项         子命令          命令选项          参数...
command [global option] [sub command] [command option] [parameter...]

有一些文章会用 flag 来指代 option ，本文全用 option 。

执行过程 Execution​

在本设计中，CLI 的执行过程为

  1. 命令启动

  2. 载入相关配置，权重从 全局 - 项目 - 环境变量 - 选项 逐级升高

  3. 解析选项与参数

    1. 调整配置项，可选过程
    2. 确定具体执行命令
    3. 确定执行参数

  4. 执行命令，输出结果或处理异常

因此，要重点设计以下几个方面：

  • 配置 Configuration

  • 参数解析 Argument Vector

  • 命令执行 Command Execution

  • 错误处理 Error Handling

  • 交互 User Experience

配置 Configuration​

配置的作用主要是帮助确定当前命令执行的上下文环境 (Context) ，所以配置要尽可能早地完成实例化。

在后续的参数解析过程中，也许会对配置进行修改。这个修改依然要早于真实的命令执行。

前面提到配置的权重问题，其实就是一个配置覆盖问题。

全局配置

权重最低。全局配置主要是为了 兜底 (fallback) 或者 默认 (default) ，避免遇到执行时配置未定义的错误。

项目配置

权重高一级，可选。项目的存在能够实现项目之间的配置自定义，避免项目之间同时写全局配置而引起冲突。

环境变量

权重高一级，可选。环境变量的存在意味着在 CLI 真实执行时，临时修改某个配置项但是不改动配置文件。

选项

权重最高，可选。与环境变量的作用一样，只是呈现为不同的修改形式，修改时机。环境变量可以在配置实例化的时候就可以生效，而选项至少要等到参数解析之后，才能对配置项进行修改。

参数解析 Argument Vector​

参数解析主要作用是为了确定具体执行的命令接受到的是什么选项，什么参数。

解析主要就是校验存在性与合法性。

存在性是指传入的选项、参数是被定义过的，遇到无法识别的就抛出错误。

合法性是指选项、参数能够正确的转换到目标数据类型。

解析完成后会涉及到两个细节， 执行命令 和 命令参数 。

一级命令设计对绝大多数 CLI 来说已经足够了。复杂场景如 git 才涉及 子命令 (sub command) 。不过子命令的设计有助于划分命令的 模块 (module boundary) 。

命令参数的定位就等同于调用函数时的传参。这已经是属于具体逻辑的范围了，不做展开。

命令执行 Command Execution​

命令执行可以是由一级命令直接调用具体函数来完成。这种做法显得太朴素了。

借助策略模式，命令执行通过分发，在具体实现类中去执行。分发的形式可以与前面提到的 模块划分 结合起来，有利于代码结构设计。

错误处理 Error Handling​

在 执行过程 中可以看到整体过程是串行的。因此错误处理设计显得比较容易：

  • 整体上做一个全局兜底错误处理。

  • 流程的每一步都可以抛出各自的错误处理。

严格来说，错误处理不算是 CLI 工具必要内容，但是良好的错误处理设计有益于对 CLI 的整体架构。

交互 User Experience​

部分场景下，需要与用户进行交互或者信息展示，如询问密码 (prompt) ，确认步骤执行 (confirm) ，进度条 (progress) 等。

良好的交互反馈能够降低用户执行命令时的等待焦虑。

其他 Miscellany​

以下省略一些比较小的细节设计，有兴趣的读者建议自己实践、自己总结。

  • 命令别名 (command alias)
  • 测试 (testing)
  • 调试 (debugger)
  • 日志 (logger)
  • 文档 (documentation)
  • 输出格式 (output)
  • 自动补全 (<tab> autocomplete)

总结 Wrap up​

从软件的层面来看，CLI 工具只是一个很小的应用。那些适用于设计一个健壮的应用的原则，同样适用于 CLI 设计。

entry.title: 架构设计的一些哲学经验
entry.summary: 经过多个项目的洗礼，得到了一些简单的架构设计经验，下面的内容从程序角度来展开，不涉及产品层面的功能设计。
entry.content:
经过多个项目的洗礼，得到了一些简单的架构设计经验，下面的内容从程序角度来展开，不涉及产品层面的功能设计。

所谓架构设计，核心要点就两个问题

  1. 模块划分，划分依据是什么

  2. 模块联系，联系媒介是什么

模块划分 Module Boundary​

划分模块，背后的意义就是封装，各种设计模式的原则均有指导，随便列几个， 单一职责原则（Single Responsibility Principle） ， 开闭原则（Open-Close Principle） ， 依赖倒置原则（Dependence Inversion Principle） 。

划分模块的好处太多了，复用、单测、替换、封装，不一而足。

上升到应用层面，模块有时候也被称为组件。各个组件按照某种划分，处理自身关心的业务逻辑，通过某种通信机制，与其他模块联系。

模块联系 Module Connection​

模块之间的联系，是架构的核心所在，也是各种不同架构模型的特点。

比如 SpringBoot 中的 依赖注入 方式，将各个 Service 联系起来了。

Egg.js 作为一个封装 Koa 的 NodeJS 服务端框架，Application / Context 对象中会挂载多个实例。这些实例其实已经有变相的 “依赖注入” （injection） 意味。

除了依赖注入下，模块之间直接依赖（引用）之外，还有 事件驱动（Event-Driven） ，通过某个全局或单例的事件触发，将各个模块联系起来。

VS Code 的命令系统就是如此。全局拥有一个 Command 系统，不同的模块向 Command 注册命令，回调函数。其他模块调用 命令，传入参数，等待执行结果。

事件驱动有很多种变形，如 消息队列 ， 发布-订阅 ， 生产者-消费者 等等。

上升到跨进程、跨应用的层面，产生了 socket，IPC 和 网络 等联系媒介。此时，考虑的架构主体发生了升级。

比方说，当设计一个操作系统时，应用视作模块，各自搬砖，应用之间联系则可以通过 socket 通信（当然还有其他的方式）。

比方说，设计 kubernetes 的时候，不同都 Service 应用视作模块，通过 Ingress 进行联系（此处屏蔽了很多细节，不做过多展开）。

写这两小节时，我脑中突然想起了 Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs 这本书。该书在解释计算机程序执行、实现的过程中，也解释了程序设计的一些原则。极力推荐。

哲学思考​

大部分设计模式书籍通常会给出一些实际例子，解释设计，顺带给出一些设计原则。但是逃不开上面两点考量。

现在把上述设计思路推广到公司架构设计。

一个公司需要各个部门，如采购、生产、仓储、运营、市场、销售、客服、研发、行政、GP 等等，解决公司存续、发展时的各种事情。这就是模块划分。

各个部门之间通过办公协同软件沟通、对齐目标、同步信息、任务派发与推进。这就是模块联系。

再往上，可以推广到各种社会组织，我就不举例了（手动狗头）。

直接到最高境界

  1. 模块划分，就是将整体拆解到局部，分。
  2. 模块联系，就是局部重新组成整体，合。

收回到这篇文章，各个小节分别展示观点，这就是分，所有小节的主线就是为了说明架构设计，这就是合。

Q.E.D

entry.title: Electron 应用的理想架构设计
entry.summary: 最近在折腾 Electron 相关的应用，一口气跟着 Udemy 的教程学了一些入门级的开发实践，如 Electron for Desktop Apps Build Desktop Apps With JavaScript 。这些课程通过几个小巧的应用来介绍如何使用 Electron 开发，都是比较适合新手入门。
entry.content:
最近在折腾 Electron 相关的应用，一口气跟着 Udemy 的教程学了一些入门级的开发实践，如 Electron for Desktop Apps: The Complete Developer's Guide，或者 Electron From Scratch: Build Desktop Apps With JavaScript 。这些课程通过几个小巧的应用来介绍如何使用 Electron 开发，都是比较适合新手入门。

但是咱也想达到登堂入室的层次呀，VS Code 的代码实在难啃。所以找了几个项目复杂度中等的开源项目学习了一波。

Motrix​

Motrix 是一个界面非常友好的下载器，主要技术栈包括了 Electron 、 Vue 、webpack 等。

代码结构很清晰，解决问题时使用的 npm package 也很简单。值得学习。

下面简单说明一下 Motrix 中 Main 和 Renderer 的架构划分。

虽然 Main 里面没采用已有的 DI 框架，但是其中单例模式的使用处处可见。

扩展 Electron 类型的 d.ts 。

Main 负责的功能

  • 实例化 Launcher ，主要处理 app 层面的事件，如 文件打开，单例窗口 等。

  • 实例化 Application 应用模块，响应 renderer 的事件，然后交给各个单例去执行。

  • Application 继承于 Node 原生的 EventEmitter ，内部维护的单例包括有

    • 配置 Configuration （依赖于 electron-store）
    • 菜单 Menu
    • 系统托盘 Tray
    • 下载引擎 Aria2 （下载工具）
    • 程序坞 Dock（macOS 专属）
    • Touch Bar （macOS 专属）
    • 电池模块 （electron 提供的 powerSaveBlocker）
    • 文件处理 （应用打开 BT 文件直接打开时响应）
    • 窗口管理 （renderer 启动的 BrowserWindow 统一管理）

Renderer 负责的功能

主要负责用户的交互，主要使用了 Vue 作为 UI library。组件通过 Vuex 触发，再借由 ipcRenderer 与 Main 进行通信。

Vuex 承担了状态管理的职责，VueRouter 承担了 SPA 中页面切换的职责。

在 Main 中，ipcMain 监听到的事件又回通过 Application 进行 emit ，触发后续动作。

整体

套用主流 web 应用的视角，就能很容易理解 Motrix 的架构设计。

  • Main 相当于一个 Server，处理各种涉及 OS 的操作，如数据持久化、系统级的事件响应。
  • Renderer 相当于 Web 界面，响应绝大部分的用户交互，Renderer 几乎没有任何 OS 相关的工作量。
  • ipcMain / ipcRenderer 约等于网络，承载了通信职责。

Hyper​

hyper 的是一款基于 Electron 的命令行终端。

Renderer

可以说是标准的 React 应用了，技术栈主要是 react + redux。

终端实例 则封装了 XTerm。

Main

显然，Renderer 不太会执行很重的进程逻辑，它通过 ipcRenderer 向 Main 发送任务消息，Main 进程执行 exec 或者 execFile ，并将结果 stdout 和 stderr 的信息反馈回去。

通信 Message

作为一个终端，hyper 免不了要管理多个 BrowserWindow 实例。为了解决通信问题，hyper 在每个 BrowserWindow 创建的时候，main 进程一方面通过 Set 存储了该实例，另一方面给该实例增加了一个 rpc 属性 ，提供了 main->renderer 消息发送的快捷方式。 同时在 BrowserWindow 内部，window 全局也挂了一个 rpc 对象，提供 renderer->main 消息发送的快捷方式。

命令 commands

Main 和 Renderer 都维护了的命令集 Map<string,callback> 。这样一来，事件的调用就会变得很容易。

可能是因为没有具体场景，hyper 并没有实现注册机制。

Wexond Browser​

这是一个套 Electron 的浏览器。

Main

通过阅读 application.ts 的代码，不难发现其采用了单例模式。

StorageService 负责存储，具体媒介采用了 nedb 。

WindowsService 负责管理多个 AppWindow （封装的 BrowserWindow ） 实例，每个 AppWindow 实例通过 ViewManager 管理多个 BrowserView 实例，这些 View 就是最终呈现 浏览器地址 内容的页面载体。

DialogService 则会挂到 BrowserWindow 上，成为一些用户交互组件，例如 搜索框 。

Main 的 webpack.config.js 中有关于 Hot Reload Electron 的思路可以借鉴一波。

Renderer

AppWindow 会载入 app.html ，成为一个具有 Tab 栏 + 工具栏（含地址框） + 书签栏 + 页面载体的 初始化 窗口。app.html 其实占据的内容非常有限，只是窗口顶部一小部分。

app.html 加载完成后（跳过很多实例化过程），其内在 store service 会 ipcRenderer 发送一条 views-create-${windowId} 的事件，Main 进程中对应 windowId 的 BrowserWindow 会调用其专属的 ViewManager 创建对应的 tab ，创建完之后进行 select ，选择了激活的 tab view 页面 主体，同时会 setBounds 完全占据窗口的下半部分。

通信

项目使用了专门封装的 @wexond/rpc-electron 来解决通信问题，这样在 Renderer 和 Main 之间就不需要直接的 send / on 事件了，而且类型推导变得更加方便。思路是非常好的，具体实现可以看其源码。

VS Code​

VS Code 的 Renderer 比 Main 做的事情要重很多，也难怪 VS Code 逐渐开始吃内存了。

关于 VS Code，网上关于 VS Code 架构设计、源码分析的文章一抓一大把，而我鉴于能力有限，只能说一点点皮毛。

  • VS Code 自己实现了一套依赖注入了，DI 的使用极大地简化了代码之间的引用问题。
  • Renderer 进程不仅仅是个用户交互响应，还承担了大量的 OS 相关工作，举例如每个编辑器窗口都有自己的插件进程。
  • Event 的设计，使得事件监听变得容易溯源，不再会 on / emit 满天飞了，而且类型推导也变的很容易实现。
  • 命令系统 / Action 的设计，使得 service 的依赖可以在一定程度上解耦，也为后续 extensions 提供命令调用/命令注册的自由带来了可能性。（坏处就是 调用 不能在第一时间溯源到 注册）
  • ProxyChannel 取代了直接使用 ipcMain / ipcRenderer 的通信，能够支持 browser window 之间的通信。
  • （想到了再补充，其实就是鸽了的意思）

重新设计​

下面基于 Electron，设计一款我想要的桌面应用软件架构。

Main 和 Renderer 均采用某种 DI 框架。不同的 BrowserWindow 中，各自具有独有一颗 DI 树。（我就是这么喜欢依赖注入）

Main 必要地维护以下功能

  • Store 持久化数据的抽象
  • Message 消息中心，封装 ipcMain 的功能，承担 Main<-->Renderer 之间通信任务
  • Command 以命令系统代替 Service 之间的直接依赖
  • Context Main 执行的上下文，基本上就是 app 相关功能的扩展
  • Logger 日志系统
  • Network 统一的网络基础，方便代理的配置
  • WindowManager 管理各个 BrowserWindow 的实例
  • Configuration/Preference 配置内容
  • User 用户数据
  • Menu 封装 app 相关菜单功能，可以实现菜单的变更
  • AutoUpdater 应用自动更新机制

Main 可选的功能有

  • Metrics 监控系统
  • Theme 主题配色支持
  • Tray 封装 Electron 的 Tray 功能，实现系统托盘图标相关功能
  • Notification 封装后的通知功能，系统级别的消息通知
  • ChildProcess 某些任务通过子进程的形式去执行，减轻 Main 的压力
  • EventEmitter service 之间可能存在相互监听的需要，通过 生产者-消费者 的模式来解决问题

Renderer 则响应用户交互，形态为基础 web 应用 + Node features

  • 任意的前端框架、UI 库均可，呈现 web
  • Store 状态管理工具
  • Router 路由，页面动态切换
  • Network 必要的网络请求基础
  • Message 消息中心，与 Main 通信的唯一 “掮客” ，很多功能需要 Main 来执行或分发。

Renderer 可选的功能

  • ChildProcess BrowserWindow 也是个 Node 环境，因此可以将任务派给子进程。
  • Command 命令系统，解耦 Service，参考 vscode ，每个编辑器 window 都有一块自己的命令系统实例。
  • EventEmitter service 之间可能存在相互监听的需要，通过 生产者-消费者 的模式来解决问题

事实上，上述设计思路可以应用到 Electron 以外的任意桌面应用开发。

那么，你会怎么设计 Electron 应用呢？

entry.title: Type vs Interface
entry.summary: It's recommended to go through the section Item 13: Know the Differences Between type and interface in the book Effective TypeScript written by Dan Vanderkam.
entry.content:
It's recommended to go through the section Item 13: Know the Differences Between type and interface in the book Effective TypeScript written by Dan Vanderkam.

In most cases, they are interchangeable when doing type gymnastics.

type TA = { };
interface IA = {};

type TB = TA & {};
interface IB extends IA {};

class A implements TA {};
class AA implements IA {};

However, there are some features you can only express with type, not interface.

Union

There's no syntax available when writing unions with interface.

type TC = TA | IA | {};
// oops, there's no union of interfaces.

Tuple

You can't create a tuple directly from interface.

type Pair = [number, string];
type StringList = string[];
// oops, there's no tuple directly from interface

However, here's a trick way to express tuple in interface

interface ITuple {
  0: number;
  1: string;
  length: 2;
}

const x: ITuple = [42, '42'];

Mapped types

It's invalid to distribute types in interface.

type Fruit = 'apple' | 'orange' | 'banana';

// this is ok in type
type FruitCount = {
  [key in Fruit]: number;
};

// oops, this is invalid
interface FruitCount {
  // error, ts(7061)
  [key in Fruit]: number;
}

In general, it's more safe and robust to use type.

I set up consistent-type-definitions rule in my eslint config.

@typescript-eslint/consistent-type-definitions: [ 'error', 'type']

But, interface does have one ability that type doesn't.

I haven't find more, maybe add more in the future.

Declaration merging (augment)

interface IA {
  name: string;
}
interface IA {
  age: number;
}

const a: IA = { name: 'n', age: 2 };

There's one blog provided by TypeScript team that talks about the preferences when considering compile performance. Take a look if you're interested.

In conclusion, You'd better know the differences between interface and type, and make the decision that's suitable for your project.

entry.title: 重构 Electron 应用之后的感悟
entry.summary: 自从转岗以来，基于 Electron 开发编辑器应用已经快半年了，主要载体是 VS Code 。
entry.content:
自从转岗以来，基于 Electron 开发编辑器应用已经快半年了，主要载体是 VS Code 。

现行的架构主要是利用 VS Code 提供的插件系统，注入相应的业务实现。该方案有很大的性能问题，是业务组件只能 VS Code 编辑器启动之后，才能初始化、实例化，性能有很大影响。另外，鉴于业务实现都跑在 VSC 的插件进程系统，通信显然会成为问题。

当业务复杂度上升之后，当前的设计方案会成为一个瓶颈。

这两个月刚好赶上了重构，主要思路就是将组件模块化， VSC 变成应用的一个模块，亦即编辑区，原先的插件式组件，升级成为与 VSC 同等级的模块。有这样的设计，应用的横向扩展性、模块间的联系性都能得到很大的提升。

那么我感悟到的是什么？并不是代码怎么重构、模块怎么实现，而是关于项目管理、展开、推进的。

Angular is the BEST! Nx.dev also!

  1. 对齐各方目标。

    要完成一个时间跨度长、工作量大的项目，第一条就是对齐各方目标，明确项目的目标，收益（向上管理的时候需要）。把各方的 KPI / 绩效考核 拉齐，这样容易让他们在这个事情上投入，也有理由给他们以反馈。

  2. 对齐项目方案。

    凡事欲则立，不预则废。项目方案没有考虑周全，各方协调没有到位，容易出现信息差，或者重复工作，最终就是导致返工，拖垮战线。

    如果是项目中的某一方，建议多投入，以全局的视角去分析，自身模块所处的位置，然后再确定方案，与整体方案相统一。

    如果是 Owner，则更要注意对齐各方的方案、信息了，因为整个项目的责任在自己身上。不然以后报告的时候，“负责 XX 项目，积极推动 YY” 就不好说咯。

  3. 小周期对齐进度，及时暴露风险点。

    这个算是老生常谈了，有的同事闷声不响的，一问才发现配环境配三天，开发进度 0 。

    在小公司经常搞每日站会就是这个道理，小地方耗不起的。（幺蛾子的另说）

差不多就这些了，结尾放个炒饭吧。无 P 无修，累了。

entry.title: 今天给摩托车上牌啦～
entry.summary: 因为疫情管控，居住所在地的车管所的新车上牌只能通过线上预约的形式取号。
entry.content:
因为疫情管控，居住所在地的车管所的新车上牌只能通过线上预约的形式取号。

冬天的早上是很冷清的。我早早到了车管所，但是车管所一定要等到 8:30 才开门。

不过验车区的人已经开始检查车辆了。辅警同志看到我的车上还有尾箱就告诉我，“箱子拆掉，下面的塑料板也要拆掉”。

我一时没了主意，就问哪里有没有修车铺一样的。辅警同志叫我去对面小区碰碰运气。

我忽视了车垫子下其实原厂有一个小工具袋的，里面刚好有扳手等工具，当然这是后话了。

运气比较好，小区一层商铺里面有一家修电瓶车的铺子。我就找老板借了点工具自己拆箱子。 UY 的箱子很好拆。拆的过程中，老板给我来了一句很恶心人的话：“你拆随你拆，待会儿装不要在这里装。”

我一听就急了，“我就借你点工具，又不是让你动手。这样也不行？”

“我这里是修电瓶车的，不是修摩托车的。”

“那我给你十块钱，你工具借我，我自己装回去，行不行？”

“不行。” 老板说完就走开了。

没办法，我只好先去把车给验了先，箱子等会儿在路上找个新的修车铺再解决吧。

验车倒是很顺利，辅警同志手法也很熟练。但是呢，核验材料的时候，辅警同志说我提供的材料中缺少一张蓝色的发票注册联。

所以我要先去车行找老板找回我的发票注册联。

尾箱问题转机就在出现了。在车行老板寻找发票的时候，我就三下五除二地把尾箱又给装回去了。不得不说，以后换个大一点的箱子也很简单了。

拿到了蓝色的注册登记联，我立刻赶回车管所去交材料。后续的流程就顺畅的很多了，取号、登记、选牌、缴费。

本人对牌照的号码没有特别偏好，随手选的 455 ，接下来就等邮政快递寄送了。

这里有个尴尬的地方，快递员说邮政快递是到付的。但是我隐约记得车管所缴费的费用中已经包含了快递费，难道真的是我记错了？。

不过，人证车齐全了，合法安全上路！

entry.title: 考出摩托证并喜提新车
entry.summary: 期待了很久，终于要考摩托了。早上安排了科二和科三，如果科二科三都通过了，就会安排下午的科四考试。所以顺利的话一天内就把摩托 D 照给考出来了。
entry.content:
期待了很久，终于要考摩托了。早上安排了科二和科三，如果科二科三都通过了，就会安排下午的科四考试。所以顺利的话一天内就把摩托 D 照给考出来了。

这个时候，富阳的摩托车考试还是人力监考的，并没有使用上红外线监考。

我在考科二的第一把绕杆回程的时候，因为紧张（其实是方向打早了）而擦到了杆子。监考员的哨子立刻响了起来，等于是我第一把不通过。

我的教练忙里偷闲的过来，询问我咋回事，你当时又没有按照我的点位教的来学，转弯的时候要多转一点。

一起考试的学员建议道，“因为场地反光明显，所以监考员是不容易发现地面压线问题的”。科二的第二把，我在绕杠的时候转弯打方向多打一点，地面上稍微压压线没问题的。当我绕杠结束之后，可以用如释重负来形容。

科三可以说是极其简单，绕场地开一圈就好了，注意转向灯的使用就行了。但就是这样，也有人挂过一次，因为她路线走错了，未按要求车道行驶。

早上的考试进行的很快，整个考场大概 100 号人，通过的有近 80 人，不知道红外电子考的通过率会不会也有这么高。

中午，跟几个同行的学员到富阳的万达广场（高桥），一起 AA 吃了一顿谭鸭血火锅。广场周围的万达房子还在造，并没有交付。这个地方就在地铁 6 号线高桥站的附近，交通上来说是很方便的，不到一小时就能到滨江了。高桥的房子比滨江的房子要便宜很多，借助地铁，性价比着实提升了不少。

下午的科四其实简单得很，不值一提。二楼考试，一楼拿证，C1D，实习期为一年。

当天就去车行提车了。提车前我还问题了一下拥有忍者 400 玉米同学，我要是提车开回来的路上，没有头盔怎么搞呢？老司机玉米的回答是 请你带着头盔去提车，谢谢。

那我只好坐公交车先回家，拿上我的 LS2 头盔，再坐公交车去车行提车。来回折腾 1 个小时多，到车行的时候快 4 点半了。

车子老早就定了，UY 125 百年版。原车自带尾箱，日常就是我放头盔的地方。这个时候老板给我来了一句 现在才来提车，保险不一定出的来啊。保险出不来，临牌就不好申请了 ，企图浇一盆冷水在我头上。好在手续办的快，刷卡交钱。老板娘在微信上找保险业务员买交强险，赶在了五点前让保险生效。然后老板娘给我个车管所地址，我又赶在了五点半车管所下班前把临牌给申请出来了。申请临牌不需要验车，只需要材料就好了。

此刻，又一位高贵的踏板车主登场了。

entry.title: Fun with Chrome Devtools Protocol
entry.summary: The Chrome DevTools Protocol allows for tools to instrument, inspect, debug and profile Chromium, Chrome and other Blink-based browsers.
entry.content:
The Chrome DevTools Protocol allows for tools to instrument, inspect, debug and profile Chromium, Chrome and other Blink-based browsers.

The most familiar Chrome DevTools uses this protocol to help debugging webpages.

Under the hood, the protocol relies on WebSocket to work, wiki. The commands and events are serialized JSON objects on the protocol.

The package chrome-remote-interface is a good tool, and we are going to demonstrate some cases with it.

Debugging a node process​

First let's start a node process with inspect option.

$ node --inspect=9222 server.js

# output
Debugger listening on ws://127.0.0.1:9222/d4231410-13e5-463d-a5ba-23d206432a35
#                       ^ debugger endpoint

Example express server.
const express = require('express');
const app = express();
const port = 3000;

const marquee = ['log', 'warn', 'debug', 'error'];

let id = 0;
function nonce() {
  id = (id + 1) % 4;
  const method = marquee[id];
  console[method](`${method} works`);
}

app.get('/', (req, res) => {
  nonce();
  res.send('Hello World!');
});

app.listen(port, () => {
  console.log(`Example app listening at http://localhost:${port}`);
});

With chrome-remote-interface, it's very easy to connect to the debugger endpoint.

const CDP = require('chrome-remote-interface');

const client = await CDP({
  target: 'ws://127.0.0.1:9222/d4231410-13e5-463d-a5ba-23d206432a35',
});
const { Debugger, Console, Runtime } = client;
client.on('Runtime.consoleAPICalled', (params) => {
  console.log('received: ', params);
});
await Runtime.runIfWaitingForDebugger();
await Runtime.enable();
await Debugger.enable({
  maxScriptsCacheSize: 10000000,
});
await Console.enable();

Each time the server process invokes methods on console, we would receive the payload.

received:  {
  type: 'warning',
  args: [ { type: 'string', value: 'warn works' } ],
  executionContextId: 1,
  timestamp: <timestamp in number>,
  stackTrace: {
    callFrames: [
      // ... omitted
    ]
  }
}
received:  {
  type: 'log',
  args: [ { type: 'string', value: 'Visit /' } ],
  executionContextId: 1,
  timestamp: <timestamp in number>,
  stackTrace: {
    callFrames: [
      // ... omitted
    ]
  }
}

And we will get the available protocol if visiting http://localhost:9222/json/protocol.

protocol json 
{
  "domains": [
    {
      "description": "This domain is deprecated - use Runtime or Log instead.",
      "deprecated": true,
      "domain": "Console",
      "commands": [
        // ...
      ],
      "types": [
        // ...
      ]
      // ...
    },
    {
      "domain": "Debugger",
      "dependencies": ["Runtime"]
      // ...
    },
    {
      "domain": "HeapProfiler",
      "dependencies": ["Runtime"],
      "experimental": true
      // ...
    },
    {
      "domain": "Profiler",
      "dependencies": ["Runtime", "Debugger"]
      // ...
    },
    {
      "domain": "Runtime",
      "events": [
        {
          "name": "consoleAPICalled",
          "parameters": [
            // ...
          ],
          "description": "Issued when console API was called."
        }
        // ...
      ]
    },
    {
      "deprecated": true,
      "domain": "Schema",
      "description": "This domain is deprecated."
      // ...
    },
    {
      "experimental": true,
      "domain": "NodeTracing"
      // ...
    },
    {
      "domain": "NodeWorker",
      "experimental": true
      // ...
    },
    {
      "domain": "NodeRuntime",
      "experimental": true
      // ...
    }
  ],
  "version": { "major": "1", "minor": "0" }
}

According to the document, the protocol in node only has few domains. We're very limited to debug the remote node process.

Debugging a webpage​

This is much easier to debug a webpage since we could use the already powerful Devtools built with Chrome.

The quick way is to open chrome://inspect/#pages and you can start debugging.

But how to debug the webpage using chrome-remote-interface ?

First, we need some webpage running with available debugging port.

In this case, we'll start with the electron quick-start project.

After cloning and installing the dependencies, add a line before app.whenReady() in main.js to enable remote debugging.

+ app.commandLine.appendSwitch('remote-debugging-port', '9222');

// This method will be called when Electron has finished
// initialization and is ready to create browser windows.
// Some APIs can only be used after this event occurs.
app.whenReady().then(() => {

So the time we start the application using npx electron .， it would output something like this

DevTools listening on ws://127.0.0.1:9222/devtools/browser/a1df1a72-9dce-42ad-80ed-d8765dbb7520
#                       ^ devtools debug endpoint

However, this websocket url is only a devtools debug endpoint, not the chrome devtool protocol debug endpoint. We have to visit the http://localhost:9222/json to find out the real webSocketDebuggerUrl for chrome-remote-interface to connect.

Example output 
[
  {
    "description": "",
    "devtoolsFrontendUrl": "/devtools/inspector.html?ws=localhost:9222/devtools/page/D6F9769D8A20DCF2E8F574D231F9A8C6",
    "id": "D6F9769D8A20DCF2E8F574D231F9A8C6",
    "title": "Hello Vanilla!",
    "type": "page",
    "url": "file:///Users/workspace/quick-start/index.html",
    "webSocketDebuggerUrl": "ws://localhost:9222/devtools/page/D6F9769D8A20DCF2E8F574D231F9A8C6"
    //    ^ debugger endpoint
  }
]

With the webSocketDebuggerUrl, we can write some code to interact with the webpage.

const CDP = require('chrome-remote-interface');

const options = {
  target: 'ws://localhost:9222/devtools/page/D6F9769D8A20DCF2E8F574D231F9A8C6',
};

CDP(options, async (client) => {
  console.log('Connected!');
  const { Page } = client;
  await Page.enable();

  await Page.navigate({ url: 'https://cn.bing.com' });
  await Page.loadEventFired();
  client.close();
}).on('error', (err) => {
  console.error(err);
});

You'll find out the page is navigated if you check out the electron window.

We have more abilities to manipulate the webpage. Just take a look at the listed protocol.

Tricky​

Look at the output json, there's a property named devtoolsFrontendUrl.

We would get the devtool panel if visiting http://localhost:9222/<devtoolsFrontendUrl>. Then open the devtool for the devtool page, for example, press F12 or cmd+option+I.

We will find the message communication in devtool panel Network>WS.

These are the commands sent via chrome devtools protocol, we could do the same thing using chrome-remote-interface.

References​

  • Chrome Devtools Protocol

  • chrome-remote-interface

entry.title: Class Asynchronous Initialization
entry.summary: Sometimes, the instance of Class is not completely initialized yet when we first see it, because its property is initialized asynchronously.
entry.content:
Sometimes, the instance of Class is not completely initialized yet when we first see it, because its property is initialized asynchronously.

class A {
  data: string;
  constructor() {
    // asynchronous data
    Promise.resolve('data').then(d => void this.data = d);
  }
}

const a = new A();
assert.equal(a.data, undefined);
setTimeout(() => {
  assert.equal(a.data, 'data');
}, 0)

Here are some simple solutions.

promise-based constructor​

We delay access to the instance of Class until it is fully initialized by returning a Promise from the constructor.

class A {
  data: string;
  constructor() {
    // asynchronous data
    return Promise.resolve('data').then((d) => {
      this.data = d;
      return this;
    });
  }
}

new A().then((a) => {
  assert.equal(a.data, 'data');
});

It's kind of surprising to have a constructor return a Promise instead of an instance.

static factory method​

A static factory method of a Class creates instances and is an alternative to using new Class().

class A {
  data: string;
  constructor(d: string) {
    this.data = d;
  }
  static async create() {
    // asynchronous data
    const data = await Promise.resolve('data');
    return new this(data);
  }
}

A.create().then((a) => {
  assert.equal(a.data, 'data');
});

factory function​

Stand-alone functions as factories are occasionally useful.

class A {
  data: string;
  constructor(d: string) {
    this.data = d;
  }
}

async function createA() {
  // asynchronous data
  const data = await Promise.resolve('data');
  return new A(data);
}

createA().then((a) => {
  assert.equal(a.data, 'data');
});

private constructor via secret token​

If we want to ensure that instances are always correctly set up, we must ensure that only the static factory can invoke the constructor of Class. We can achieve that via a secret token:

// module variable, closured
const aToken = Symbol('aToken');

class A {
  data: string;
  constructor(token: Symbol, d: string) {
    if (token !== aToken) {
      throw new Error('Constructor is private');
    }
    this.data = d;
  }
  static async create() {
    // asynchronous data
    const data = await Promise.resolve('data');
    return new this(aToken, data);
  }
}

A.create().then((a) => {
  assert.equal(a.data, 'data');
});

There's a variant way to achieve the same purpose.

class A {
  data: string;
  constructor() {
    throw new Error('Constructor is private');
  }
  private _init(d: string) {
    this.data = d;
    return this;
  }
  static async create() {
    // asynchronous data
    const data = await Promise.resolve('data');
    return Object.create(this.prototype)._init(data);
  }
}

A.create().then((a) => {
  assert.equal(a.data, 'data');
});

entry.title: Test-Driven Development in FrontEnd
entry.summary: A quick summary on how to write tests in frontend framework. Using ReactJS as example codes, but these principles are also suitable for other frameworks such as Vue.js or Angular.
entry.content:
A quick summary on how to write tests in frontend framework. Using ReactJS as example codes, but these principles are also suitable for other frameworks such as Vue.js or Angular.

How to test shared utilities​

It's time for jest testing .

How to test components​

mount / render without problem

it('renders without crashing', () => {
  const div = document.createElement('div');
  ReactDOM.render(<App />, div);
  ReactDOM.unmountComponentAtNode(div);
});

expect some specific html tag or text content to be correct

it('renders the app and the heading', () => {
  const wrapper = mount(<App />);
  expect(wrapper.find('h1').text()).toBe('Hello React');
  expect(wrapper.find('.counter label').text()).toBe('Current');
  expect(wrapper.find('.counter span').text()).toBe('0');
});

expect user event works well, and mutate the state correctly

it('should increment the count by one', () => {
  const wrapper = shallow(<Counter />);
  expect(wrapper.find('.counter span').text()).toBe('1');
  wrapper.find('.counter').simulate('click');
  expect(wrapper.find('.counter span').text()).toBe('2');

  wrapper.find('.counter').simulate('click', { shiftKey: false });
  expect(wrapper.find('.counter span').text()).toBe('3');

  wrapper.find('.counter').simulate('click', { shiftKey: true });
  expect(wrapper.find('.counter span').text()).toBe('12');
});

expect some callback to be called correctly

it('should call the handler on click', () => {
  const handler = jest.fn();
  const wrapper = shallow(<Counter count={1} onCounterIncrease={handler} />);
  wrapper.find('.counter').simulate('click', { shiftKey: false });
  expect(handler).toBeCalledWith({ shiftKey: false });
});

it('should call the instance method correctly', () => {
  const wrapper = shallow(<App />);
  const instance = wrapper.instance();
  expect(instance.state.count).toBe(0);
  instance.increment(false);
  expect(instance.state.count).toBe(1);

  instance.increment(true);
  expect(instance.state.count).toBe(11);
});

expect some time-relevant callback take side effect correctly

jest.useFakeTimers();

test('waits 1 second before ending the game', () => {
  // some rendering and user event action
  expect(setTimeout).toHaveBeenCalledTimes(1);
  expect(setTimeout).toHaveBeenLastCalledWith(expect.any(Function), 1000);
});

expect side effect works correctly

this can also be tested in e2e testing such as Cypress.

// react testing library
it('should change the document title correctly', () => {
  act(() => {
    ReactDOM.render(<Counter />, container);
  });
  const button = container.querySelector('button');
  expect(document.title).toBe('You clicked 0 times');

  act(() => {
    button.dispatchEvent(new MouseEvent('click', { bubbles: true }));
  });

  expect(document.title).toBe('You clicked 1 times');
});

Also, we can use cypress for component testing.

How to test a module or a big component?​

It's just a component with bigger construction.

How to test the whole application​

It's job for Cypress. Also,

Testing in SSR​

Some projects use next.js to leverage SSR. It's recommended to run e2e testing rather than unit testing in SSR project.

  1. Angular universal use protractor as default testing framework.
  2. Nuxt.js provide several frameworks to choose from, namely Jest, AVA, WebdriverIO, Nightwatch.
  3. Next.js doesn't provide any testing framework by default.

entry.title: React Hooks Review
entry.summary: Recently, I get a little confused on how React hooks executes, and this is what I have summarized.
entry.content:
Recently, I get a little confused on how React hooks executes, and this is what I have summarized.

During the process of delving, I come across some knowledge on how V8 deals with function compilation, since we would have lots of anonymous functions (closures in some cases) defined whilst using hooks.

Get started​

Imagine we have a class component like the following one.

class Counter extends React.Component {
  state = {
    counter: 1,
  };
  render() {
    const { counter } = this.state;
    return (
      <>
        <p>current value: {counter}</p>
        {/* anonymous function */}
        <button onClick={() => this.setState({ counter: counter + 1 })}>
          Increment
        </button>
      </>
    );
  }
}

It's obvious that button would receive a new click callback after every render.

To avoid repeatedly generating the onClick anonymous function, so we have another style of function definition.

In V8, the anonymous function is only parsed once, but allocated every time execution hits the code. So we have different function every time the code runs.

class Counter extends React.Component {
  state = {
    counter: 1,
  };
  // class method
  increment = () => {
    const { counter } = this.state;
    this.setState({
      counter: counter + 1,
    });
  };
  render() {
    const { counter } = this.state;
    return (
      <>
        <p>current value: {counter}</p>
        {/* reference to the class method */}
        <button onClick={this.increment}>Increment</button>
      </>
    );
  }
}

In Functional Components, we have similar situation.

const Counter = () => {
  const [counter, setCounter] = React.useState(1);
  return (
    <>
      <p>current value: {counter}</p>
      {/* anonymous function */}
      <button onClick={() => setCounter(counter)}>Increment</button>
    </>
  );
};

Still, button would receive a new click callback after every render.

Here comes the useCallback to rescue.

const Counter = () => {
  const [counter, setCounter] = React.useState(1);
  const onClick = React.useCallback(() => {
    setCounter(counter + 1);
  }, [counter]);
  return (
    <>
      <p>current value: {counter}</p>
      <button onClick={onClick}>Increment</button>
    </>
  );
};

useCallback would return the same function as long as the dependency counter doesn't change.

So the VDOM reference stays untouched even if the function component gets re-rendered.

Now, we are going to look at a more complicated situation.

const Counter = () => {
  const [counter, setCounter] = React.useState(1);
  const [tip, setTip] = React.useState('first tip');

  const onClick = React.useCallback(() => {
    setCounter(counter + 1);
  }, [counter]);

  React.useEffect(() => {
    setTip('second tip');
  }, []);

  const [heavy, setHeavy] = React.useState({
    a: {},
    // ... some huge object
    z: {},
  });

  return (
    <>
      <p>current tip: {tip}</p>
      <p>current value: {counter}</p>
      <button onClick={onClick}>Increment</button>
    </>
  );
};

It's guaranteed there would be two render invocations. Here come the questions：

Question 1. Will the onClick functions equal to each other during these two invocations?

My Opinion

They are same functions. useCallback would return the same function as long as the dependency counter doesn't change. Internally, hook.memoizedState is not updated, so the same function is returned from same memoizedState.

Question 2. Will React.useCallback execute twice? Will each execution receive same arguments (anonymous function)?

My Opinion

useCallback is just a plain normal JavaScript function, so it executes twice.

However, the arguments are different. There will be a newly allocated local function in every execution.

Question 3. Will React.useEffect execute twice? Will each execution receive same arguments (anonymous function)?

My Opinion

useEffect is just a plain normal JavaScript function, so it executes twice.

And, each execution is invoked with a brand new allocated local function. Internally, useEffect would adjust the effect flag in hook.memoizedState according to the dependencies.

Question 4. Will React.useState execute twice? Will each execution receive same arguments (a large object)?

My Opinion

useState is just a plain normal JavaScript function, so it executes twice.

Internally, useState would memorize the value in the first execution. The arguments is ignored in the rest executions.

useState would receive a new allocated large object as arguments on each execution. And this object is eligible to be collected (Garbage collection) after execution.

Question 5. What's point of using these useCallback, useMemo, useEffect hooks? What we could do if the arguments are different?

My Opinion

hooks invocation is required by React fiber reconciliation.

Without these hooks invocation, React is unable to trace these local variables/closure objects. So React cannot perform reconciliation actively upon these objects' mutations.

With the help of these tracing, React fiber keeps its references solid, avoiding unnecessary reconciliation.

The function component might re-render and return a new VDOM. However, there will be no difference during VDOM diff comparison sine their references are same. This would result no DOM update execution, which is skipped.

The following example is more persuasive：

const Child = ({ onClick }) => <button onClick={onClick}>Click me!</button>;

const ParentWithoutHooks = () => {
  const handleClick = function () {
    console.log('clicked');
  };
  // whenever parent re-renders,
  // the Child is forced to rerender
  // since handleClick is a new function after every render
  return (
    <>
      <Child onClick={handleClick} />
    </>
  );
};

const ParentWithHooks = () => {
  const handleClick = React.useCallback(
    function () {
      console.log('clicked');
    },
    [
      /* dependencies if necessary */
    ]
  );
  // when the parent re-renders,
  // in an optimistic situation,
  // Child is only re-rendered if onClick is changed
  return (
    <>
      <Child onClick={handleClick} />
    </>
  );
};

Summary​

Most of the time it does not matter. Pay more attention to the business.

References​

  • Function compilation mechanism in V8
  • V8 closures

entry.title: Micro Frontends
entry.summary: Micro frontends deliver the same flexibility and maintainability to browser-based applications that microservices provide for backend systems.
entry.content:
Micro frontends deliver the same flexibility and maintainability to browser-based applications that microservices provide for backend systems.

The whole project is viewed as a set of standalone components, built upon any tech-stack or framework, with their own interfaces, logic, and storage. Then these mini-applications are evolving independently and will be composed together shipping to the browser.

There are several tech stacks developers can adopt to build micro frontends architecture.

Client-side integration​

Separate pages​

It's also known as Multi-Page Application, MPA.

This is simplest and easy-implementation architecture. Every application is served as a standalone service, which produce complete server-rendered HTML documents. They are connected via <a> tags.

Hard navigation among pages are triggered by clicking a link, reloading the complete page then displaying the desired content.

<!-- in app 1 -->
<div id="main-app1">
  <div id="content">
    <!-- content provided by main-app -->
    <a href="http://link-to-app2"></a>
  </div>
</div>

<!-- in app 2 -->
<div id="main-app2">
  <div id="content">
    <!-- content provided by main-app -->
    <a href="http://link-to-app1"></a>
  </div>
</div>

Iframes​

Iframes allow embedding one page into another page while maintaining the same loose coupling and robustness properties that the link integration provides.

Iframes come with strong isolation, which means what happens in the iframe stays in the iframe. But they also have significant drawbacks, such as layout constraints, performance overhead, communication complexity, SEO confusion.

<div id="main-app">
  <div id="content">
    <!-- content provided by main-app -->
  </div>
  <div id="ads">
    <iframe src="http://ads.com/{some-ads}"></iframe>
  </div>
</div>

Ajax​

Client-side JavaScript triggers the Ajax calls to fetch server-side generated HTML snippets, and then update document dynamically and partially.

Be careful, HTML5 specifies that a <script> tag inserted with innerHTML should not execute.

Using Web Components together with Ajax for internal updating is also a good fit.

Sample code.

// main app
window
  .fetch('/some-url')
  .then((res) => res.text())
  .then((html) => {
    document.querySelector('to-update').innerHTML = html;
  });

Web Components​

Web Components is an umbrella term. It describes three distinct new APIs: Custom Elements, Shadow DOM, and HTML Templates.

Web Components provides the ability to encapsulate style and business logic.

Sample code, Sample code2.

<div id="main-app">
  <custom-button type="primary"></custom-button>
</div>

<script src="http://js-define-custom-button"></script>

<!-- define the custom button -->
<script>
  window.define(
    'custom-button',
    class extends HTMLElement {
      static get observedAttributes() {
        return ['type'];
      }

      constructor() {
        super();
      }

      adoptedCallback() {
        console.log('Custom button moved to new page.');
        // using shadow DOM if necessary
      }

      disconnectedCallback() {
        console.log('Custom button removed from page.');
      }
    }
  );
</script>

Unified SPA​

The Unified SPA describes a single-page application composed of other single-page applications.

It requires all the components to be a single-page app, using Sveltejs, Angular, React, Vue, etc.

A parent application, which is often called the app shell, will unify these single-page apps into one monolithic application.

The app shell includes the single-spa JavaScript code and maps URL prefixes to the code of a specific application.

Single SPA, Ara framework.

<html lang="en">
  <head>
    <title>SPA demo</title>
    <script src="/single-spa-base.js"></script>
  </head>
  <body>
    <div id="app1-holder"></div>
    <div id="app2-holder"></div>
    <div id="app3-holder"></div>

    <script type="module">
      singleSpa.registerApplication(
        'app1',
        () => import('http://app1/pages.min.js'),
        ({ pathname }) => pathname === '/'
      );
      singleSpa.registerApplication(
        'app2',
        () => import('http://app2/pages.min.js'),
        ({ pathname }) => pathname.startsWith('/app2/')
      );
      singleSpa.registerApplication(
        'app3',
        () => import('http://app3/pages.min.js'),
        ({ pathname }) => pathname.startsWith('/app3/')
      );
      singleSpa.start();
    </script>
  </body>
</html>

Server Side Integration​

Routing with proxy​

Nginx acts as a proxy and forwards the requests to the responsible services. This could be used to unify MPA architecture.

http {
  upstream app1 {
    server localhost:3001;
  }

  upstream app2 {
    server localhost:3002;
  }

  log_format compact ':3000$uri $status';

  server {
    listen 3000;

    # comment out on windows
    access_log /dev/stdout compact;

    location /app1/ {
      proxy_pass  http://app1;
    }

    location /app2/ {
      proxy_pass  http://app2;
    }

    location /app2-new {
      proxy_pass  http://app2;
    }
  }
}

SSI, ESI, Podium​

This is similar to client-side integration Ajax.

http {
  upstream app1 {
    server localhost:3001;
  }

  upstream app2 {
    server localhost:3002;
  }

  log_format compact ':3000$uri $status';

  server {
    listen 3000;
    ssi on;
    ; ...
  }
}
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Main App</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <div class="content">
      <!-- ... -->
    </div>
    <aside class="ads">
      <!--#include virtual="/app2/fragments/ads" -->
    </aside>
  </body>
</html>

<!-- app2 html fragment for ads -->
<a href="http://ad-detail">
  <div>ads</div>
</a>

Podium: Easy server side composition of microfrontends, leveraging express.js.

Sample code for SSI, Sample code for Podium.

Universal rendering​

Universal composition is the combination of server-side and client-side composition technique.

For the first request, a technique like SSI, ESI, or Podium assembles the markup of all micro frontends server-side. The complete HTML document gets sent to the browser. In the browser, each micro frontend hydrates itself and becomes interactive. From there on, all user interactions can happen fully client-side. The micro frontends update the markup directly in the browser.

Angular universal, Next.js.

Sample code: SSI in server-side, ajax and web-component in client side.

Choose the architecture​

The decision tree helps to pick a micro frontends architecture based on the project’s requirements.

These two image comes from (https://codeburst.io/which-technique-architecture-is-right-for-my-project-72297e650af3).

Simple designed Unified SPA​

Basic mechanism: observable browser location/history, rendering path-corresponding applications.

Structure​

unified-spa/
  ├─ app-shell/
  │  ├─ src/
  │     ├─ index.css
  │     ├─ index.js
  │     ├─ index.html
  │     ├─ layout.js
  ├─ parcel1/
  │  ├─ src/
  │     ├─ favicon.ico
  │     ├─ index.html
  │     ├─ index.js
  ├─ parcel2/
  │  ├─ src/
  │     ├─ image.png
  │     ├─ index.html
  │     ├─ index.js
  ├─ README.md
  ├─ .env

Development​

Only the app-shell server is running, all the other app-parcels would generate their static assets (js bundles, images, style assets) into app-shell's output directory.

Distribution​

Build app-shell first, then every app-parcel.

Concerns​

  • Global state.
  • Style isolation: BEM, css module, shadow DOM.
  • Communication among app-parcels: event bus, broadcast channel, event bus.
  • Shared vendor or dependencies: unified tech stack, vendor version.
  • Assets updating: cache invalidation strategy.

Glossary​

namedescription
app-shellapp shell for layout, responsible for micro apps register/unregister
app-parcelmicro autonomous interactive applications

My Opinion​

Micro frontends majorly focus on the integration. Application integrates components. Micro-frontend integrates micro-apps.

It's recommended to do the integration during building/distributing stage, so the end user feel little latency when using the application.

References​

  1. Micro Frontends in Action: An excellent starting point to understand micro frontends. Sample code for this book.

  2. SSR: Render and update markup on the server and in the browser using single code-base. Universal JavaScript, Isomorphic JavaScript

entry.title: TypeScript handbook
entry.summary: A quick cheat sheet for TypeScript.
entry.content:
A quick cheat sheet for TypeScript.

  • Basic Types
  • Interfaces
  • Functions
  • Unions and Intersection Types
  • Classes
  • Generics
  • Utility Types
  • Decorators
  • Declaration
  • TSConfig

Useful References​

TypeScript Handbook

TypeScript Deep Dive

React+TypeScript Cheatsheets

Basic Types​

Simple units of data such as numbers, strings, booleans, structures.

Boolean​

let isDone: boolean = false;

Number​

let decimal: number = 6;
let deci_mal: number = 100_000;
let hex: number = 0xf00d;
let binary: number = 0b1010;
let octal: number = 0o744;
let big: bigint = 100n;

String​

let color: string = 'blue';
color = 'red';
// and template strings
let fullName: string = `Bob Bobbington`;
let age: number = 37;
let sentence: string = `Hello, my name is ${fullName}. I'll be ${
  age + 1
} years old next month.`;
// ^ let sentence: string =
//    'Hello, my name is ' +
//    fullName +
//    '.\n\n' +
//    "I'll be " +
//     (age + 1) +
//    ' years old next month.';

Array​

let list: number[] = [1, 2, 3];
// generic array type
let list: Array<number> = [1, 2, 3];

/_ Array as Tuple _/;
// Declare a tuple type
let x: [string, number] = ['hello', 10];
x[2] = 'world'; // error, no element at index 2

Enum​

enum Color {
  Red /* = 0, inferred */,
  Color /* = 1, inferred */,
  Blue /* = 2, inferred */,
}
let c: Color = Color.Green;

enum Color {
  Red = 1,
  Green /* = 2, inferred */,
  Blue /* = 3, inferred */,
}
let c: Color = Color.Green;

enum Color {
  Red = 1,
  Green = 2,
  Blue = 4,
}
let c: Color = Color.Green;

enum Color {
  Red = 1,
  Green /* = 2, inferred */,
  Blue /* = 3, inferred */,
}
let colorName: string = Color[2];

// Displays 'Green'
console.log(colorName);

// string enums
enum Direction {
  Up = 'UP',
  Down = 'DOWN',
  Left = 'LEFT',
  Right = 'RIGHT',
}

// Technically enums can be mixed with string and numeric members,
// but it’s not clear why you would ever want to do so.
// OK but why.
enum BooleanLikeHeterogeneousEnum {
  No = 0,
  Yes = 'YES',
}

// reverse mappings
enum Enum {
  A,
}

let a = Enum.A;
let nameOfA = Enum[a]; // "A"

Unknown​

This variable could be anything.

let notSure: unknown = 4;
notSure = 'maybe a string instead';

// OK, definitely a boolean
notSure = false;

Any​

We might want to opt-out of type checking.

declare function getValue(key: string): any;
// OK, return value of 'getValue' is not checked
const str: string = getValue('myString');

let looselyTyped: any = {};
let d = looselyTyped.a.b.c.d;
//  ^ = let d: any, type inference is propagated

Void​

The absence of having any type at all.

function warnUser(): void {
  console.log('This is my warning message');
}

You would get and type error if you assign null to a void variable (only if --strictNullChecks is not specified).

let unusable: void = undefined;
// OK if `--strictNullChecks` is not given
unusable = null;

Null and Undefined​

// Not much else we can assign to these variables!
let u: undefined = undefined;
let n: null = null;

Never​

The never type represents the type of values that never occur. For instance, never is the return type for a function expression or an arrow function expression that always throws an exception or one that never returns.

// Function returning never must not have a reachable end point
function error(message: string): never {
  throw new Error(message);
}

// Inferred return type is never
function fail() {
  return error('Something failed');
}

// Function returning never must not have a reachable end point
function infiniteLoop(): never {
  while (true) {}
}

Object​

object is a type that represents the non-primitive type, i.e. anything that is not number, string, boolean, bigint, symbol, null, or undefined.

Generally, use Type or Interface rather than object.

declare function create(o: object | null): void;

// OK
create({ prop: 0 });
create(null);

create(undefined); // Remember, undefined is not a subtype of null
// Argument of type 'undefined' is not assignable to parameter of type 'object | null'.

create(42);
// Argument of type '42' is not assignable to parameter of type 'object | null'.

create('string');
// Argument of type '"string"' is not assignable to parameter of type 'object | null'.

create(false);
// Argument of type 'false' is not assignable to parameter of type 'object | null'.

Type Assertions​

Type assertions are a way to tell the compiler trust me, I know what I’m doing.

A type assertion is like a type cast in other languages, but it performs no special checking or restructuring of data.

It has no runtime impact and is used purely by the compiler.

// as syntax
let someValue: unknown = 'this is a string';
let strLength: number = (someValue as string).length;

// angle-bracket syntax
let someValue: unknown = 'this is a string';
let strLength: number = (<string>someValue).length;

Interfaces​

This is sometimes called duck typing or structural subtyping.

function printLabel(labeledObj: { label: string }) {
  console.log(labeledObj.label);
}

// more properties is fine
let myObj = { size: 10, label: 'Size 10 Object' };
printLabel(myObj);

// --- equivalent

interface LabeledValue {
  label: string;
}

function printLabel(labeledObj: LabeledValue) {
  console.log(labeledObj.label);
}

let myObj = { size: 10, label: 'Size 10 Object' };
printLabel(myObj);

Optional Properties​

interface SquareConfig {
  color?: string;
  width?: number;
}

function createSquare(config: SquareConfig): { color: string; area: number } {
  let newSquare = { color: 'white', area: 100 };
  if (config.color) {
    newSquare.color = config.color;
  }
  if (config.width) {
    newSquare.area = config.width * config.width;
  }
  return newSquare;
}

let mySquare = createSquare({ color: 'black' });

Readonly properties​

Some properties should only be modifiable when an object is first created.

Variables use const whereas properties use readonly.

interface Point {
  readonly x: number;
  readonly y: number;
}

let p1: Point = { x: 10, y: 20 };
p1.x = 5; // error!

let a: number[] = [1, 2, 3, 4];
let ro: ReadonlyArray<number> = a;
ro[0] = 12; // error!
ro.push(5); // error!
a = ro; // error!

a = ro as number[]; // OK

Excess Property Checks​

interface SquareConfig {
  color?: string;
  width?: number;
}

function createSquare(config: SquareConfig): { color: string; area: number } {
  return {
    color: config.color || 'red',
    area: config.width ? config.width * config.width : 20,
  };
}

let mySquare = createSquare({ colour: 'red', width: 100 });
// Error, compiler think it is a potential bug

let mySquare = createSquare({
  colour: 'red',
  width: 100,
} as SquareConfig);
// OK

Conditional Types​

Conditional types help describe the relation between the types of inputs and outputs.

interface Animal {
  live(): void;
}
interface Dog extends Animal {
  woof(): void;
}

type Example1 = Dog extends Animal ? number : string;
//   ^ = type Example1 = number

//   ^ = type Example2 = string

  ? NumberType
  : StringType;

type Flatten<Type> = Type extends Array<infer Item> ? Item : Type;

Distributive Conditional Types​

When conditional types act on a generic type, they become distributive when given a union type.

Typically, distributivity is the desired behavior. To avoid that behavior, you can surround each side of the extends keyword with square brackets.

type ToArray<Type> = Type extends any ? Type[] : never;
type StrArrOrNumArr = ToArray<string | number>;
//   ^ = type StrArrOrNumArr = string[] | number[]
//   ^ !! not <string | number>[]

type ToArrayNonDist<Type> = [Type] extends [any] ? Type[] : never;
// 'StrOrNumArr' is no longer a union.
type StrOrNumArr = ToArrayNonDist<string | number>;
//   ^ = type StrOrNumArr = (string | number)[]
//   ^ !! not string[] | number[]

Class Types​

Explicitly enforce a class meets (implements) a particular contract (interface).

Interfaces describe the public side of the class, rather than both the public and private side.

interface ClockInterface {
  currentTime: Date;
  setTime(d: Date): void;
}

class Clock implements ClockInterface {
  currentTime: Date = new Date();
  setTime(d: Date) {
    this.currentTime = d;
  }
  constructor(h: number, m: number) {}
}

When a class implements an interface, only the instance side of the class is checked. Since the constructor sits in the static side, it is not included in this check.

See the following example.

interface ClockConstructor {
  new (hour: number, minute: number);
}

class Clock implements ClockConstructor {
  // Error
  // Class 'Clock' incorrectly implements interface 'ClockConstructor'.
  // Type 'Clock' provides no match for the signature 'new (hour: number, minute: number): any'.
  currentTime: Date;
  constructor(h: number, m: number) {}
}

// --- fix it

// constructor interface
interface ClockConstructor {
  new (hour: number, minute: number): ClockInterface;
}

// class interface
interface ClockInterface {
  tick(): void;
}

// factory function
function createClock(
  ctor: ClockConstructor,
  hour: number,
  minute: number
): ClockInterface {
  return new ctor(hour, minute);
}

class DigitalClock implements ClockInterface {
  constructor(h: number, m: number) {}
  tick() {
    console.log('beep beep');
  }
}

class AnalogClock implements ClockInterface {
  constructor(h: number, m: number) {}
  tick() {
    console.log('tick tock');
  }
}

let digital = createClock(DigitalClock, 12, 17);
let analog = createClock(AnalogClock, 7, 32);

// ---
// Another simple way is to use class expressions:

interface ClockConstructor {
  new (hour: number, minute: number): ClockInterface;
}

interface ClockInterface {
  tick(): void;
}

// class expressions
const Clock: ClockConstructor = class Clock implements ClockInterface {
  constructor(h: number, m: number) {}
  tick() {
    console.log('beep beep');
  }
};

let clock = new Clock(12, 17);
clock.tick();

Discriminating Unions​

type NetworkLoadingState = {
  state: 'loading';
};

type NetworkFailedState = {
  state: 'failed';
  code: number;
};

type NetworkSuccessState = {
  state: 'success';
  response: {
    title: string;
    duration: number;
    summary: string;
  };
};

type NetworkFromCachedState = {
  state: 'from_cache';
  id: string;
  response: NetworkSuccessState['response'];
};

// Create a type which represents only one of the above types
// but you aren't sure which it is yet.
type NetworkState =
  | NetworkLoadingState
  | NetworkFailedState
  | NetworkSuccessState;

function logger(state: NetworkState): string {
  // Right now TypeScript does not know which of the three
  // potential types state could be.

  // Trying to access a property which isn't shared
  // across all types will raise an error
  state.code;
  // Error
  // Property 'code' does not exist on type 'NetworkState'.
  // Property 'code' does not exist on type 'NetworkLoadingState'.

  // By switching on state, TypeScript can narrow the union
  // down in code flow analysis
  switch (state.state) {
    case 'loading':
      return 'Downloading...';
    case 'failed':
      // The type must be NetworkFailedState here,
      // so accessing the `code` field is safe
      return `Error ${state.code} downloading`;
    case 'success':
      return `Downloaded ${state.response.title} - ${state.response.summary}`;
  }
}
